hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the input matrix. It is a 2D array where each integer should ideally appear once, except for one integer that appears twice and another that is missing.
Consider how you can traverse the matrix to collect all the numbers. You might want to use a set or a dictionary to track which numbers you have seen as you iterate through the matrix.
Think about how you can determine the range of numbers you should be checking. The numbers will be in the range from 1 to n^2, where n is the size of the matrix.
You need to identify two key values: the missing number and the repeated number. As you collect numbers, keep track of duplicates and also check against the expected range to find the missing number.
When you find a number that is repeated, store it. You can use a simple condition to check if the number is already in your collection of seen numbers.
To find the missing number, you can create a complete set of expected numbers from 1 to n^2 and compare it with the set of numbers you have collected from the matrix.
Remember that the matrix is 0-indexed, so ensure that you correctly access elements using the appropriate indices. For example, to access the first element, use grid[0][0].
Consider edge cases where n is at its minimum value (2). Make sure your logic handles the smallest input correctly.
Once you have both the repeated number and the missing number, return them in the specified format: an array where the first element is the repeated number and the second is the missing number.

You are almost there! After collecting the numbers and identifying the repeated and missing values, your final step will be to construct the return array. Make sure to check that your logic correctly identifies both values.

questionNotes: Each integer appears exactly once except for one that appears twice and one that is missing.
The integers are in the range [1, n^2].
Return format: an array where ans[0] is the repeated number and ans[1] is the missing number.
